Title: NBA 2K24: A Disappointing Struggle with Microtransactions and Unfulfilled Promises

NBA 2K24 has arrived, and while it promised improvements and innovation, it seems to have stumbled in several critical areas, leaving fans and gamers disappointed. The most glaring issue that continues to plague the series is the presence of egregious microtransactions, which, sadly, seem to be even more pervasive than ever.

One of the most significant letdowns for players is the game's failure to deliver on the promise of cross-play functionality. This was a feature that was eagerly anticipated and much-hyped prior to the game's release. Yet, upon playing, gamers discovered that this long-awaited feature was nowhere to be found. The absence of cross-play is a major setback, especially in a sports game that thrives on the community aspect and competition among players across different platforms.

On the positive side, the gameplay in NBA 2K24 has seen improvements, making for a more enjoyable on-court experience. The mechanics feel smoother, and there's a certain level of realism in player movements and interactions that enhance the immersion. However, these improvements are overshadowed by the persistent bugs that continue to haunt the franchise. Glitches, AI quirks, and animation issues can disrupt the flow of the game and diminish the overall experience.

Furthermore, there's a noticeable lack of polish throughout NBA 2K24. It feels rushed, as if the developers didn't have enough time to refine the game before release. This lack of attention to detail is particularly evident in the presentation and various modes, leaving players longing for the level of quality they expect from a franchise of this caliber.

Perhaps one of the most disheartening aspects of NBA 2K24 is its failure to represent the values and ethos that Kobe Bryant, a beloved basketball icon, stood for. Kobe was known for his dedication, work ethic, and passion for the game, and his untimely passing left a profound impact on the basketball world. It's unfortunate that the game bearing his name falls short in capturing the essence of what he represented, both as a player and as an inspirational figure.

In conclusion, NBA 2K24 arrives as a disappointing addition to the franchise. While it does show promise with improved gameplay, it falters due to its continued reliance on microtransactions, the absence of promised cross-play, persistent bugs, and a lack of overall polish. This game fails to honor the legacy of Kobe Bryant and leaves fans hoping for better days for the NBA 2K series.

Next, and worst of all.  This Legendary Path.  They leave it up for two weeks and say if you get it you can get a super high graded Shaq.  Sounds good right? Wrong.  It was a lie.  After you buy it?  They add another one.  And another one.  Wait... Another one.  I spent all my MT and Gold getting the first two only for them to add another.  Wait, it gets worse.  Now you only have 36 hours to get the new legendary path.  Price if the new one?  200k MT or 150k Gold.  If you don't get it?  No Shaq.  And it is impossible to not get it without spending $200.  Can't get worse right?  They added another one.  Bigger price. 

Oh!  And they capped your MT gains.  You can only get 4k a game.  On 2K23 you could get triple that in one full 13 man game on Pro. Now?  It will show you that you should have gained 12k.  Just to piss you off.  But you are walking away with 4k.

Alright, I will leave an actual review, instead of just calling 2k "racist towards pc" (which they are). I personally am enjoying the game, but that is because I play with my brother and I took 2k23 off, so I have been waiting over a year to play 2k.

In this game, 2k really did less then the bare minimum. Literally the only thing new in this game is the park design. Everything else is the same (or has been completely removed).

This game is not next gen, which is a huge slap in the face to the PC community, since PC hardware is so much better than that of the PS5 or XBOX. They say nobody plays the game on PC, but clearly that is a flat out lie based on all of these reviews.

Aside from not being next gen, here are the other issues I have with the game:

1. No voice chat - This has been an issue on PC for forever, and makes the game feel kind of lonely. Why is voice chat not enabled? I cant talk to the people I play with or attempt to make new friends over the game. Not having voice chat in 2024 is just unacceptable.

2. No myCareer story - They removed the story entirely, so there is basically no reason to play single player myCareer. If I want to play single player games, I will just use player lock on myLeague. 

3. MyCareer is too hard - I usually play myCareer on HoF difficulty, but this year it is impossible to do so. My teammates cannot make a single open shot and ALWAYS take contested layups or midranges. On the other hand, the CPU makes everything they take, even if they are contested. I even dropped the difficulty down to allstar, and it is still not enjoyable.

4. No Myteam - Never really got into myteam, but they basically took it out entirely. I feel bad for anyone who actually bought 2k for myTeam.

5. Season progression is WAY too fast with NO rewards - I have played 16 rec games in 17 hours on the game, and I am already lvl 40 on the season pass with 39 days until the season ends. What am I supposed to play for now? There are no good rewards in this game that warrant me to put the time in. I feel bad for anybody that bought the season pass, because the rewards are awful. You unlock mascots, but not really. You unlock the OPPORTUNITY to spend $100 worth of VC to buy one.

6. Too many hackers - There has got to be an anticheat...there just has to be. Park is LOADED with hackers, like literally one on every court. Rec isnt as bad as park, but I have played with one on my team, and it just made the game not enjoyable. This is only day 5, I am sure they will get worse as time goes on.

7. Everything is too expensive - 2k forces you to spend money on VC if you want the game to be at least somewhat enjoyable. The 100k VC I got from the League pass edition only put my character to a 72 OVR, that is just not fun. Now I can only get 1000 VC per game, which means I have to play like 300 games just to get my player to a 99...Ill pass on that.

In conclusion, these are the main complaints I have, but I am sure as I keep playing I will find more. The fact that they took away more features than they added - and charged FULL PRICE - should be illegal. This game can be fun, and I am sure I will enjoy myleague (I hope), but it should be $10 MAX. I hope 2k listens to these reviews, since it is now top 2 in all time negative reviews on steam.

I never write reviews, but this game is such an egregious step backwards I really felt compelled to share my experiences as someone who played a lot of NBA 2k23 WITHOUT purchasing any microtransactions.

Despite 2k23's notorious and very real predatory monetization practices I was able to play the game as a SINGLE-PLAYER game due to a relatively robust MyCareer mode in '23.  There was a "story" with "choices" of varying quality, but regardless provided a way to play the game and develop your player without having to spend money on microtransactions.  The career mode was more than enough "game" for me that I never felt the need to play online until I had completed several full seasons, and by then had a pretty solid build that I could at least keep up online if I wanted to (again, without spending any money on VC because I was able to earn it through the pretty fun single-player game).

2k24 essentially REMOVES THE SINGLE PLAYER MODE FROM THE GAME.  Yes you can still create a player, but they've removed all of the actual content down to just the basketball games, so there is little motivation to grind game after game without it being broken up by the story beats, player choices, and some interesting challenges that fed into the overall narrative in '23 (ex, playing through your college games).

So what is 2k24 offering players other than a new location and updated rosters?  After 2 hours it felt like LITERALLY the exact same game as '23 but with a large chunk of content removed.  I refunded and will just re-install '23 if I want to play more bball.

I understand that the majority of NBA 2k players are in it to spend a ton of money on VCs so they can "compete" online...  If you are someone who just enjoys the NBA and the game of basketball 2k23 at least gave us a story mode which gave me some fun and a reason to "grind" up my character.  With this removed 2K is telling me they only want me playing online and they removed the most interesting (and microtransaction-free) way to build my character, essentially pushing players strongly to skip everything and go straight into online, which obviously will encourage players to spend more $.

Yuck.  Don't buy this game.

NBA 2K24 has arrived, and for many fans of the series, it's been a letdown. Despite the name change, it feels like a minor update at best, with the previous installment, NBA 2K23, offering a more enjoyable experience overall. In this review, we'll break down the reasons why NBA 2K24 falls short and why some of the decisions made by the developers have left players feeling frustrated.

Lack of Innovation: NBA 2K24 disappointingly fails to bring any significant innovation to the table. Many expected a leap forward in gameplay mechanics, graphics, or features, but instead, the game feels like a slight rehash of its predecessor. It's clear that the developers prioritized incremental changes over groundbreaking improvements.

Stale Gameplay: The gameplay in NBA 2K24 feels eerily similar to NBA 2K23, which makes one wonder why this game needed to exist in the first place. The core mechanics, animations, and AI behavior have seen only marginal adjustments, if any. This lack of innovation results in a stagnant gaming experience for long-time fans.

Questionable Decisions: It's hard not to mention the controversy surrounding Mike Wang and Ronnie, who are often perceived as being disconnected from the community. Fans have expressed their frustrations with their decisions regarding player ratings, in-game purchases, and the overall direction of the franchise. These controversies have left a sour taste in the mouths of many players.

Inconsistent Visuals: While NBA 2K games have been praised for their realistic graphics, NBA 2K24 has its share of graphical inconsistencies and glitches that disrupt the immersion. These issues can be distracting and take away from the overall experience.

Overall Experience: NBA 2K24 falls short of expectations and does not justify the purchase for players who already own NBA 2K23. It lacks innovation and fails to address the concerns of the community. The questionable decisions made by the development team and the continued emphasis on microtransactions are frustrating for fans of the series.

In conclusion, NBA 2K24 feels like a missed opportunity to take the franchise to new heights. It's a game that fails to distinguish itself from its predecessor and leaves players longing for a more innovative and satisfying basketball gaming experience. Whether the feedback from fans will lead to meaningful changes in future iterations remains to be seen, but for now, NBA 2K24 leaves much to be desired.

CHEATERS Galore on PNO

Been playing 2K on PC since 2K15, and played consoles on and off for years before that.  This is the only time I've ever felt compelled to write a review because everyone knows we're getting last gen (no way I'm calling Xbox X and PS5 next gen when they're half a decade old), everyone knows MyTeam is an arcade money grab, and everyone knows our pool of players is just smaller.

The reason I'm recommending to stay away is that I have had success avoiding the usual PC cheaters that plague Rec and Park by sticking to Play Now Online.  Sure every once in a while in earlier versions you'd come across people who greened 99% of shots regardless of defense, or position as long as they were past half court, or you'd match up against the infinite steal gods, but that was sporadic.  This year though, I've matched against more clear cheaters in the few days it's been out than any other year (not combined obviously), and it sucks the fun out of games.

Besides the regular all green cheaters, there's the losers that pause, cause the game to have an error and disconnect, and then are awarded the W.  Why play multiplayer online if you're going to cheat?  How is that fun?  Why doesn't 2K have an easy cheat report option like every other game in 2023?  

I'm not a salty noob either.  I play over 1k games of PNO yearly, and my average win rate is 76% with varied teams.  I've played this game enough to instantly recognize cheating, and have accepted it will happen in small doses on PC because that's a natural outcome to a game where developers don't care about your platform, and on a system that makes cheating inherently easier than consoles.  But at the current rate I'm just gonna wait until more people buy the game so I have less of a chance of meeting those same people that gotta cheat to win.

Very disappointed with this version of the Game

This version of the game was advertised very vaguely. "Use the revamped player builder to create a MyPLAYER that suits your skillset, so you can play to your strengths and get the most out of the updated Badge system." As the consumer I assumed that we would also get the builder from next gen from the words "revamped player builder" and "updated Badge system". Was I wrong? Not entirely but the "revamped player builder" was from the Nba 2k23 next gen.  

As a player that kept coming back to the pc version of the game because of the love of basketball, I was hoping for something refreshing with the build. But no, we get the same things from last year with just a "fresh start".  

I do not know anything from the marketing/business side of 2k but pc players should have the option to buy next gen or current gen just like ps4/ps5. Pc are powerful enough to run next gen games and I see no other reasons to not offer the option to have next gen.  

Overall, very disappointed with the pc version of the game. Your best interest would to save the money and buy another game or invest into a next gen console to play the game if you want to.

This has to be the most stripped down, copy pasted NBA I've seen this far and I've been playing 2K since 2K10. Everything looks identical with a different skin, probably patched together by a few interns.

Gameplay wise there is not much different other than changed sliders and a few new animations. Basically it's easier to score now and defense also got a bit of a boost. Other than that the game hasn't changed at all. Cheaters in the game within 24 hours.

Awards are locked behind a paywall and it's super easy to gain levels this year. I think this was done intentionally to get people to buy this battlepass to get the rewards. You can even buy these levels, but what sane person would buy them if you get a level basically every game?

On top of everything - they added a bunch of lights to kill epileptic people.

1/10. Shame.

Tl;dr – PLEASE DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!  These points are ordered by most to least annoying, but please don’t let the order of my personal gripes with the game make you think that this game could possibly be worth your money.  Please do not buy this game.  It is bad.

1.	Constant Crashes – I have a decent computer, and it runs games fairly well.  I can play games like Baldur's Gate and Hell Let Loose (far more demanding games) without any issue.  I can barely get through two games of NBA 2K24 before the game crashes, and I have tried almost everything.  This is my biggest gripe with the game and the reason that I am writing this review, because despite the game being extremely bad every single year, at least in past years I could actually play the game.  In 2K24, I can barely even start playing it before it crashes, even though I can play much more graphically intense games without issue.  

2.	Rampant Cheating – Please don’t think that I or anyone else is understating the amount and level of cheating that goes on in this game.  In past years of 2K on PC there has been the same level of cheating, and this year is no different, even though some of us hoped that it would be. 

When I say cheating is rampant, I mean rampant.  Every second game that you play online in 2K will have someone cheating.  2K has never, and in all likelihood will never, do anything about these cheaters.  They are blatant, and they are everywhere.   The players who are cheating are not hiding, they’re not covert, they do not bother to even attempt to hide that they’re cheating, because they know for a fact that they will not be punished for it.

3.	Next Gen and Removed Features – If you know anything about 2K on PC, you will know that 2K has never given PC players the “next gen” version of the game that PS5 and Xbox players get.  2K gives PC players the “current gen” version of the game, which is a completely different game.  Let me be clear, the next gen and current gen versions of the game are two completely different games. I don’t mean that the graphics are different, I mean nearly everything from top to bottom is different.  The current gen version of the game is always embarrassingly bad compared to the next gen version, but the amount of effort that 2K has put into the current gen version of the game has been steadily getting worse and worse over the years, and is exceptionally bad this year.  

Just as a small example of things getting worse over time, in 2K22 there was a game room with a cool prize wheel (and a bunch of other mini games around it) that you could spin every day to get a fun little reward for your character like clothing, power-ups, and other things.  In 2K24, it’s literally a signpost in the ground that says “DAILY PRIZE” on it.  You click it, and receive your reward.  This is the definition of low effort, and it is embarrassingly bad.  I know this might sound like it’s not a big deal if you haven’t experienced it, but so much of the game is like this and it’s jarring when you see it.

If that example was too small for you, we can talk about the complete lack of a story line in 2K24 on current gen.  In past years, although it was less immersive than the next gen story line, there was still a story line that you could take part in on current gen (although that experience had also been steadily eroded for quite some time).  In 2K24, you are instantly in the starting line up on your team, there is no story at all, shoe deal on game three.  Truthfully, the story lines in 2K were always lame and you would probably skip large portions of it, but sometimes there were some decent memes that came out of how ridiculous it was, and there was the (very) rare piece of dialogue that was actually funny or interesting.  Regardless of how lame the story line was though, it’s just another piece of the game that has been stripped away, and for what?  What did we get instead of the story line?  Did the developers spend more time on making the actual basketball aspect of the game better?  Possibly, but I seriously doubt it.




That’s all I can think of for now.  If you made it this far, thank you for reading.  I’m sure there’s more I could type out, but I think I’ve covered the worst parts of the game (in my opinion) well enough.  I never write Steam reviews unless I really can’t stand a game and the way it treats its players, or I really love it and want to let others know about it.

Please do not buy this game.

I've played terrible games before, but it's extremely rare to come across a game that actively hates me for playing it. I don't play 2k because I like this game or this series, I play 2k because I like basketball and it's literally the only option. Every game mode has it own unique way of attempting to squeeze every dollar it can out of the player, as if the game isn't already costing at least $60 with a new one coming out every year. There are very few changes year to year, the things that do changes are small tweaks that somehow end up costing the player even more money. Charging for a season pass in a full priced game is a scam. Removing the auction house in MT is a subtle but aggressive move towards shutting down the internal economy of the game and forcing otherwise resourceful players to spend money on in game currency. It feels targeted. It feels like the devs are pissed that I would dare to only spend $60 on a new game at launch. The amount of gambling mechanics lazily shoveled into this single game is mind boggling. I could go on, but I'm just so fucking tired

This might actually be one of the worst NBA 2K games I've played. 

Pros:
 - Kobe is on the cover 

Cons:
 - Didn't get the 100K VC (mamba edition) A fix online says to restart the game and if that don't work uninstall the game and reinstall. Exactly what I wanna do reinstall a 120+ gb game.

(UPDATE: After deleting and reinstalling all mamba edition items showed up including the 100K VC, but still an inconvenience.)
 
 - The park, what the hell happened here, who thought it would be a good idea to make a directory and have more loading times, it really defeats the purpose and takes away from buying a bike and/or skateboard. 2K should have really stuck with a more open world concept.   
 - No story line for MyCareer.
 - The amount of forced shots teammates do in the 3v3 VR is ridiculous. Along with the amount of shots taken with players back to the basket.
 - There is also one shot i have yet to see miss, but what happens is when a player is driving to the basket and another player goes underneath in front, the player with the ball brings the ball down below their waist and then brings is back up for a little lay-in. I see it happen a lot in the VR 3v3 Simulation games at My Court and it hasn't missed yet.
 - Created a 6'7"SF with a 6'6" wingspan and because MP is a 60 overall i get out rebounded by Steve Nash, somethings just don't make sense. Because your overall is so low no matter how many good shot contests you have you won't ever stop the offense.
 - Movement is clunky, i play better defense walking around than i do in a defensive stance. 
 - Passing delays happen from time to time with teammates and MP. I passed the ball when the player was open but MP didn't pass the ball until after my teammate took 5 more steps, which then my pass got stolen. MP called for a pass cutting wide open to the basket but the teammate didn't pass the ball until the defender caught up to me, which then forced me to take a bad shot near the hoop. 
 - PG was dribbling down court (ball on outside hand), MP was running along side of him and I hit the steal button MP stopped and swatted at where the ball was as the PG continued dribbling down court. It shouldn't take an 80 overall in stealing to know a player is not going to stop and swat at the ball when they would simply try to poke or hit it away. 

Conclusion:
 - It feels like 2k put all their resources in one basket when they took a year off to fix their WWE game and that ended up compromising their NBA 2K game. The game itself just does not play, feel, and look like an NBA 2K game.
 
 - Do yourself a favor and don't waste your money on this game.

If you're a basketball enthusiast, it's hard not to be intrigued by NBA 2K24. This annual installment of the popular basketball video game franchise has always been a go-to for fans like me. However, as much as I enjoy the gameplay, there's a critical element that I feel has been lacking - a compelling narrative in the MyCareer mode.

For many of us, MyCareer is the heart and soul of the NBA 2K series. It's the mode where we get to experience the journey of a budding basketball star firsthand. Each year, we anticipate that this mode will evolve, offering us richer and more immersive storytelling options. With the advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), there's tremendous potential to take MyCareer to new heights. 

In conclusion, Dont take me wrong! I enjoy playing this game but while I remain a devoted fan of basketball and the NBA 2K franchise, I cannot help but express my profound disappointment with NBA 2K24's MyCareer mode. It's disheartening to see such potential go unrealized. As fans, we long for a MyCareer experience that truly captivates us, with rich storytelling and impactful decision-making. It's my hope that the developers will heed this feedback and prioritize the narrative aspect in future releases, so we can once again embrace the MyCareer mode as the heart and soul of NBA 2K.

If you purchase the game, prepare to take a loss to every hacker as you essentially have no chance now that your shot timing has to be PERFECT to even compete. I have loved the franchise for so long, but the flat out neglect the company has for the PC gamer is out right ROBBERY. They take your money, hand you the same exact game with a different colored court, and say go fuck yourself sucker. Not to mention, PC still has the old gen version of the game, which I don't think anyone could ever make sense of. I feel scammed and robbed, and I PROMISE, you will too.

As a die-hard fan of the NBA 2K series, I eagerly awaited the release of NBA 2K24, expecting the MyCareer mode to once again captivate me with an engaging storyline. To my utter disappointment, this installment chose to completely abandon any semblance of a narrative, leaving players with a hollow, directionless experience.

Gone are the days when the MyCareer mode was a dynamic and immersive journey, where you forged your path to NBA stardom through trials and tribulations. In NBA 2K24, the absence of a storyline is nothing short of a colossal letdown. It's as if the developers decided to scrap all creativity and innovation, opting for a bland, lifeless shell of a game mode.

Without a storyline to guide your player's journey, you're thrown into the NBA without purpose or motivation. There's no rags-to-riches tale, no rivalries, and certainly no character development. Instead, you're left to aimlessly grind through endless games with no narrative thread to weave it all together. It's like playing a glorified exhibition match simulator, and it gets old fast.

The MyCareer mode used to be a unique opportunity for players to become emotionally invested in their created character's story. It allowed us to experience the highs and lows of a budding basketball career, making every victory and defeat feel meaningful. But in NBA 2K24, it's all about cold, soulless basketball statistics. There's no heart, no soul, and no reason to care about your player's journey.

The absence of a storyline has also had a detrimental impact on the game's overall immersion. Instead of feeling like an integral part of a dynamic basketball universe, you're merely a cog in the machine, endlessly grinding for meaningless rewards. The lack of narrative context for your actions makes it difficult to stay engaged, and it's hard to shake the feeling that you're just going through the motions.

In previous NBA 2K titles, the MyCareer mode was an unforgettable experience that combined basketball gameplay with a compelling story. NBA 2K24's decision to abandon this formula is nothing short of a betrayal to loyal fans. Without a storyline to anchor the mode, it feels like a shallow, uninspired addition to an otherwise great basketball simulation.

In conclusion, NBA 2K24's MyCareer mode, or lack thereof, is a severe disappointment for longtime fans of the series. The absence of a storyline robs the game of its depth, meaning, and emotional connection. It's a glaring omission that leaves players with a bland and uninspiring basketball experience. If you're looking for a MyCareer mode that actually delivers on the promise of a captivating narrative, you'll have to look elsewhere, because NBA 2K24 falls far short of expectations.

🏀 NBA 2K24: A Missed Opportunity 🎮

📣 Attention all basketball fans, it's time to discuss NBA 2K24, a game that falls disappointingly short of its potential. Despite the hype surrounding its release, this latest installment in the NBA 2K series fails to deliver an enjoyable and fulfilling gaming experience. Let's dive into some of the reasons why NBA 2K24 leaves much to be desired. 🚫

🌟 Stagnant Gameplay: NBA 2K24 feels like a rehash of its predecessors, offering little innovation or improvement in terms of gameplay. The mechanics remain largely unchanged, resulting in a monotonous and repetitive experience. The lack of fresh features and gameplay enhancements leaves players craving something new and exciting.

📉 Regressive Graphics: One would expect a visual upgrade in each new installment of a game series, but NBA 2K24 disappoints in this aspect. The graphics fail to impress, with character models lacking the level of detail and realism seen in previous versions. The overall visual presentation feels lackluster, failing to capture the essence and energy of a real NBA game.

💸 Excessive Monetization: NBA 2K24 continues the trend of aggressive monetization seen in recent sports games. The game bombards players with constant reminders to purchase virtual currency, hindering the overall enjoyment and progression. Unlocking basic features and progressing in the game becomes a tedious and expensive task, creating a sense of frustration and unfairness.

🕹️ Glitches and Technical Issues: It's disheartening to encounter a myriad of glitches and technical problems while playing NBA 2K24. From players clipping through objects to game-breaking bugs, these issues disrupt the flow of the game and hamper the overall experience. It's clear that the game was released without thorough testing and optimization, resulting in a frustrating and unpolished product.

⚠️ Lackluster Career Mode: The career mode, a highlight of the NBA 2K series, fails to provide an engaging and immersive experience in NBA 2K24. No storyline. The progression system feels slow and unfulfilling, diminishing the sense of accomplishment and progression.

📉 Overall, NBA 2K24 misses the mark and fails to live up to the expectations set by its predecessors. With stagnant gameplay, regressive graphics, excessive monetization, technical issues, and a lackluster career mode, the game leaves players longing for a more enjoyable and innovative basketball gaming experience. Let's hope that future iterations of the NBA 2K series bring back the excitement and quality that fans have come to expect. 🏀

NBA 2K24, just like its predecessors, is a classic example of how a franchise can become stagnant, offering very little innovation year after year. As a PC and Steam player, my experience with this game has been nothing short of disappointing, plagued by inequality, mistreatment, bugs, and server issues. i think if me and my friends attempted to learn computer programming for two weeks we can come up with something better than this garbage. my park is completely unplayable and pay to win.

The biggest gripe I have with NBA 2K24 is the lack of innovation. It feels like I'm playing the same game as the previous versions with a fresh coat of paint. The gameplay mechanics, graphics, and animations hardly seem to have evolved since the last installment. It's disheartening to see a franchise with such potential stuck in a never-ending cycle of repetition.

On top of that, PC and Steam players are often treated as second-class citizens in the NBA 2K community. Console players receive updates and content much earlier, leaving PC players in the dust. It's frustrating to see this level of inequality, especially when we're expected to pay the same price for the game.

Bugs and glitches have been a long-standing issue in the NBA 2K series, and NBA 2K24 is no exception. The game is riddled with numerous bugs that can significantly impact the gameplay experience. From AI issues to game-breaking glitches, it's clear that quality assurance is not a priority for the developers.

The servers in NBA 2K24 are yet another source of frustration. Frequent server outages and lag spikes make online play an exercise in patience. It's incredibly frustrating to invest time and money into a game only to be constantly reminded of its technical shortcomings.

In summary, NBA 2K24 continues the unfortunate trend of offering little innovation while perpetuating inequality and mistreatment towards PC and Steam players. The prevalence of bugs and server issues only adds insult to injury. It's high time the developers take a long, hard look at their franchise and start delivering a truly fresh and engaging basketball experience, rather than repackaging the same game year after year.
